Both this Italian writer and beo J* Wollemborg wrote their descriptions
of the Christian Democracy more than two years ago* But each had one addi¬
tional thing to say which I think helps to explain the present crisis within
the party, of which the fall of Premier Pella was a symptom.
The Italian writer said that the ingredients of the Christian Democracy
were held together by “only one agenti the fact that the party is In power.*
He said that “any shift in the political situation within the country at large
will threaten the whole structure.*
And Leo wollemborg said that it was due only to former Premier Ale id e de
Gasperl*® “singular personality, his unusual mixture of deep piety and politi¬
cal skill, that the party has held together at all.*
I say that these two assessments -• which actually contradict one another
in a sense •* help explain what is happening to the Christian Democratic party
today. The “shift in the political situation* which the Italian writer said
would "threaten the whole structure* of the Christian Democracy actually
occurred in the national elections last June ?. And if the party still is
holding together, rather than breaking up into its many ingredients, it still
is due to the prestige and power and political skill of Aloide de Gaeperi.
Political scientists and political Journalists have long sought to isolate
the Ingredients that go into the cement that keeps a great political party
intact, but all would agree, I think, that victory at the polls ranks high on
the list, and the Christian Democrats, founded on the remnants of Don Sturso*®
old Italian Popular party during World ivar IX, have been a remarkably success*
ful party, whether they made any sense in their composition or not*
In the first national postwar election in Italy — held June 2, 1946# to
elect a Constituent Assembly and render a verdict on the monarchy — the
Christian Democrats became the strongest party in the country. They got 95*2
per cent of all vote© oast*
md in the crucial national election of April 18, 19*8 — while the free
world hold its collective breath — the Christian Democrats won nearly 49 per
cent of the votes$ captured an absolute majority of seats in the Chamber of
Deputies and a comfortable plurality in the Senate. It had only about a
million party members, but got more than 12*7 million votes.
In the national election of last June 7# the Christian Democrats polled
10.8 million votes to remain the largest single party by a wide margin. 3ut
they had dropped nearly two million from their 1948 high mark and their re¬
presentation in the Chamber dropped from 305 seats to 262i
Mathematically speaking, the overall election result was not a defeat.
But the result certainly was a serious political setback and it started the
various factions of the party snarling at each other again. For the Christian
Democrats had expected to do better* They had made an electoral alliance with
th® Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans and they believed this four-
party bloc would get more than 50 per cent of the votes. They had been able
to pass an electoral law under which any group of parties getting more than
50 per cent of the votes would get nearly 65 per cent of the seats in the
Chamber, or 380 out of 590. But th© bloc failed by 57*000 votes to get its
50 per cent and wound up with a total of only 300 Chamber seats — not a
workable majority*
